title: The Monks’ Rules and Their Analysis

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14.blurb: A monk who abandons furniture belonging to the Order outdoors must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc82.translated_title: 82. Diverting gains intended for the Sangha
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc82.blurb: A monk who diverts to an individual an offering intended for the Order must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb.translated_title: The Monks’ Rules and Their Analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb.blurb: The Bhikkhu-vibhaṅga or Mahā-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the monks’ rules” or “the great analysis”), or simply the Vibhaṅga for short, contains the Monastic Code for monks, the Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Vibhaṅga is divided into eight chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”) and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter. These units begin with one or more origin stories, which tell the circumstances that led the Buddha to lay down a particular rule. The rule is then stated, followed by a word commentary that analyzes every significant word contained in the rule. After the word commentary follows a permutation series in which a variety of different scenarios are evaluated and offenses assigned as appropriate. At the end comes a non-offense clause, stating important exceptions to the rule, sometimes followed by individual case studies, in which the Buddha decides the offense incurred in ambiguous cases.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np27.blurb: If a lay person is having robe-cloth woven for a monk and that monk makes demands of the weavers, then he must relinquish the robe-cloth and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np14.translated_title: 14. Keeping a new blanket less than six years
pli-tv-bu-vb-np14.blurb: A monk who makes a blanket must wait for six years before making another. If he does not, he must relinquish it and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5.blurb: A monk who acts as a go-between for a relationship between a man and a woman is to be suspended.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc91.blurb: A monk who makes a rainy-season robe that is too large must cut it down and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc87.translated_title: 87. Making an inappropriate bed or bench
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc87.blurb: A monk who makes a bed with long legs must shorten them and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12.blurb: A monk who refuses to be corrected about breaches of the monastic code is to be suspended. The narrative setting features the monk Channa who was particularly proud and difficult to deal with.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc70.translated_title: 70. Supporting a novice monk with a bad view
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc70.blurb: A monk who lives with a novice who has been expelled for holding the view that things declared as obstructive by the Buddha are not actually obstructive must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4.translated_title: 4. Receiving food in a dangerous place
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4.blurb: A monk who receives food in a dangerous wilderness dwelling must acknowledge the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-sk.blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as sekhiya, “involving training”. There are seventy-five such rules, and they are the same both for the monks and the nuns. The sekhiyas are mostly rules of etiquette. Breaking a sekhiya is only considered to be a transgression if the offender is acting out of disrespect for the rule.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np19.blurb: A monk who receives money through trading must relinquish it and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc15.blurb: A monk who abandons bedding in a dwelling belonging to the Order must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc55.blurb: A monk who frightens another monk must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc5.translated_title: 5. Lying down with one not fully ordained
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc5.blurb: A monk who lies down in the same room as an unordained person for more than three nights must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc52.blurb: A monk who tickles another monk must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7.blurb: When a monk’s robes are lost or destroyed, he should show moderation in asking for robe-cloth. If he does not, he must relinquish the robe-cloth and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72.blurb: A monk who criticizes the monastic code must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-ss7.blurb: A monk who builds a large dwelling without getting the site approved by the Order is to be suspended.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc40.blurb: A monk who consumes unoffered food or drink must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-sk34.translated_title: 34. Not eating in the right proportions

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc85.translated_title: 85. Entering an inhabited area at the wrong time
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc85.blurb: A monk who enters an inhabited area between noon and dawn must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35.translated_title: 35. Eating more after refusing an invitation
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35.blurb: A monk who eats after finishing his meal must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pd.blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as pāṭidesanīya, “entailing acknowledgement”. There are four such rules for the monks, none of which are shared with the nuns. What distinguishes these rules from the pācittiyas is the manner of confession. For these rules the confession is done using a unique formula, with the second rule being the only one in the Monastic Code where all the offenders confess together as a group.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np15.blurb: A monk who makes a sitting-mat without including a piece from an old blanket must relinquish it and confess the offense. This rule starts with a narrative that includes several important principles of monastic law.

pli-tv-bu-vb-sk2.translated_title: 2. Not wearing the upper robe evenly all around

pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69.blurb: The background story includes the Chava Jātaka tale, “the Jātaka on the low-caste man”, found in slightly different form in the Jātaka collection.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc42.blurb: A monk who takes another monk on almsround, but then tells him to leave because he wants to misbehave, must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24.translated_title: 24. Accusing monks of teaching nuns for profit
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24.blurb: A monk who says that other monks are teaching the nuns for the sake of worldly gain, intending to discredit them, must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc65.blurb: A monk who acts as preceptor for anyone under twenty must confess the offense. And the ordination is invalid.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31.translated_title: 31. Eating excessively at a public guesthouse
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31.blurb: A monk who eats more than one meal at a public alms center must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc53.blurb: A monk who plays in water must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np.blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as nissaggiya pācittiya, “entailing relinquishment and confession”. There are thirty such rules for the monks, the same number as for the nuns, although only eighteen are held in common. These rules, together with the remaining rules of the Monastic Code, are classed as light offenses, lahukāpatti. For light offenses there is usually no penalty apart from confession. For the nissaggiya pācittiyas, however, any item involved in the committing of an offense must be relinquished. Once the offense has been confessed, the item is, with a few exceptions, returned to the offender.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3.translated_title: 3. The training rule on killing a human being
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3.blurb: A monk who kills a human being is expelled. The origin narrative to this rule includes an unusual and much debated story about a number of monks who meditate on the unattractiveness of the body. As a result they end up committing suicide and asking others to kill them. The Buddha then teaches the meditation on mindfulness of breathing.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np30.translated_title: 30. Diverting an offering intended for the Sangha
pli-tv-bu-vb-np30.blurb: A monk who diverts to himself an offering intended for the Order must relinquish the item and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8.translated_title: 8. Requesting a fine robe from a fund
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8.blurb: If a lay person wants to buy a robe for a monk, and the monk asks them for a fine robe, he must relinquish the robe and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc20.translated_title: 20. Pouring water with living beings in it
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc20.blurb: A monk who pours water containing living beings onto the ground must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc43.blurb: A monk who sits down intruding on a lustful couple must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc28.translated_title: 28. Traveling on a boat with a nun
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc28.blurb: A monk who travels on a boat by arrangement with a nun must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc17.blurb: A monk who throws another monk out of a dwelling belonging to the Order must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc62.translated_title: 62. Using water with living beings in it
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc62.blurb: A monk who uses water that contains living beings must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc92.blurb: A monk who makes a robe that is too large must cut it down and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc90.blurb: A monk who makes a bandage that is too large must cut it down and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np23.translated_title: 23. Storing the five tonics too long
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23.blurb: A monk who keeps tonics for more than seven days must relinquish them and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np21.translated_title: 21. Keeping an extra almsbowl beyond ten days
pli-tv-bu-vb-np21.blurb: A monk who keeps an extra bowl for more than ten days must relinquish it and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np13.translated_title: 13. Making a new blanket with too much black wool
pli-tv-bu-vb-np13.blurb: A monk who makes a blanket that contains more than fifty percent black wool must relinquish it and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc89.blurb: A monk who makes a sitting-cloth that is too large must cut it down and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19.translated_title: 19. Applying excessive materials to a large dwelling
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19.blurb: A monk who applies more than three layers of building material when building a large dwelling must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc47.translated_title: 47. Accepting an invitation of more than four months
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc47.blurb: A monk who goes beyond the terms of an invitation to ask for requisites must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9.translated_title: 9. Requesting a fine robe from a combined fund
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9.blurb: If two separate lay people want to buy a robe for a monk, and the monk asks them to put their money together to buy him a fine robe, he must relinquish the robe and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-sk28.translated_title: 28. Not receiving with attention on the almsbowl

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc7.blurb: A monk who teaches a woman more than six sentences of the word of the Buddha must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1.translated_title: 1. The training rule on sexual intercourse
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1.blurb: A monk who has sexual intercourse is expelled. The introduction to the rule tells the background story to the laying down of the monastic law. The main principle applied by the Buddha was to lay down rules and procedures only when required by circumstances.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc59.translated_title: 59. Using assigned property that has not been relinquished
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc59.blurb: A monk who uses robe-cloth that has been transferred to a fellow monastic must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc58.translated_title: 58. Not making stains on a new robe
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc58.blurb: A monk who wears a new robe without first marking it must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1.translated_title: 1. Sitting with a woman in a concealed place
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1.blurb: A female lay disciple may see a monk sitting in a secluded place with a woman. If she accuses him of an offense entailing expulsion, suspension, or confession, and he admits to the offense, then he incurs an offense accordingly.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33.blurb: A monk who eats a meal before an invitational meal must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc61.blurb: A monk who intentionally kills a living being must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc26.translated_title: 26. Sewing a robe for a nun
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc26.blurb: A monk who sews a robe for a nun must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5.translated_title: 5. Receiving a robe from a nun
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5.blurb: A monk who accepts robe-cloth from a nun must relinquish the robe-cloth and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc16.blurb: A monk who lies down in a dwelling belonging to the Order, encroaching on another monk and aiming to make him depart, must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1.translated_title: 1. The training rule on receiving a nun’s food
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1.blurb: A monk who receives food from a nun must acknowledge the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc66.blurb: A monk who travels by arrangement with thieves must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc10.blurb: A monk who digs the earth must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc83.blurb: A monk who enters the bedroom of a king must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc37.blurb: A monk who eats between noon and dawn must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc73.blurb: A monk who deceptively claims that he did not know a rule in the monastic code must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1.translated_title: 1. Not wearing the sarong evenly all around

pli-tv-bu-vb-np20.blurb: A monk who barters, except with fellow monastics, must relinquish the item received and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pd2.translated_title: 2. Letting a nun give directions to donors
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd2.blurb: A monk at an invitational meal who does not tell a nun to stop directing the distribution of food must acknowledge the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np1.translated_title: 1. The training rule on keeping extra robe-cloth beyond ten days
pli-tv-bu-vb-np1.blurb: A monk who keeps extra robe-cloth for more than ten day must relinquish the robe-cloth and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc88.translated_title: 88. Making an upholstered bed or bench
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc88.blurb: A monk who makes a bed with luxurious upholstery must remove the upholstery and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc78.blurb: A monk who eavesdrops on other monks who are disputing about the Teaching or the monastic law must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc32.blurb: A monk who eats as part of a specifically invited group of monks must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-ss.blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as saṅghādisesa. The meaning of the word is disputed, but according to the commentary it means that the Sangha is required at the beginning (ādi) and for the rest (sesa) of the procedure. There are thirteen such rules for the monks, seven of which are shared with the nuns. Offenders must undergo a period of probation before being rehabilitated to their former status in the Sangha.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc30.blurb: A monk who, seeking privacy, sits in private with a nun must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2.blurb: A monk who steals anything of value is expelled.

pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8.translated_title: 8. Making a groundless accusation out of anger
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8.blurb: A monk who in anger falsely accuses another monk of an offense entailing expulsion is to be suspended. The background narrative to this rule features the extraordinary monk Dabba the Mallian who became an arahant at the age of seven.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc51.blurb: A monk who consumes alcohol must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc18.translated_title: 18. Sitting down on an upper story
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc18.blurb: A monk who uses a bed with unfastened legs on an unplanked upper storey of a hut belonging to the Order must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-ss11.blurb: A monk who supports another monk who is trying to cause a schism in the Order is to be suspended.

pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10.translated_title: 10. Causing a schism in the Sangha
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10.blurb: A monk who tries to cause a schism in the Order is to be suspended. The origin story to this rule gives an account of how Devadatta, the Buddha’s notorious cousin, tried to cause a schism in the Order.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc25.blurb: A monk who gives robe-cloth to a nun must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6.blurb: When a monk builds a hut by means of begging, he must get the Order to approve the site and the hut must not exceed the maximum size limit. A monk who breaches either of these conditions is to be suspended. The origin story to this rule includes the Maṇikaṇṭha Jātaka tale, found in a slightly different form in the Jātaka collection. There is also another edifying tale and an apparent reference to Raṭṭhapāla of the Raṭṭhapāla Sutta, MN82.

pli-tv-bu-vb-ss9.translated_title: 9. Making a groundless accusation out of anger, using a pretext
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss9.blurb: A monk who in anger uses a ploy to falsely accuse another monk of an offense entailing expulsion is to be suspended.

pli-tv-bu-vb-ss4.translated_title: 4. Encouraging a woman to satisfy one’s desires
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss4.blurb: A lustful monk who recommends to a woman that they have sexual intercourse is to be suspended.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc64.blurb: A monk who conceals another monk’s serious offence must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-ss1.blurb: A monk who intentionally ejaculates is to be suspended. The introductory narrative to this and the next four rules, as well as a number of other rules in the monastic code, feature the monk Udāyī, who had a serious problem with keeping his sexual urges in check. Either that or he is a literary stand-in for the real offenders.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc81.blurb: If a monk, acting as part of a complete Order, gives away a robe to an official of the Order, but then criticizes the act, he must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np4.translated_title: 4. Having a nun wash a used robe
pli-tv-bu-vb-np4.blurb: A monk who makes a nun wash or dye a used robe must relinquish the robe and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4.translated_title: 4. The training rule on falsely claiming a superhuman quality
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4.blurb: A monk who falsely claims a profound spiritual attainment is expelled. In the origin story to this rule the Buddha declares that anyone who gets people to support him or her by lying about their spiritual attainments is the worst kind of thief.

pli-tv-bu-vb-sk32.translated_title: 32. Not eating with attention on the almsbowl

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc80.blurb: A monk who departs without giving his consent while the Order is deciding on an issue must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np29.translated_title: 29. Storing a robe for more than six days in an inhabited area
pli-tv-bu-vb-np29.blurb: A monk who stores any of his three robes in an inhabited area for more than six days must relinquish the robe and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48.translated_title: 48. Going to see a mobilized army
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48.blurb: A monk who goes to see an army in action must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36.translated_title: 36. Encouraging a monastic to eat after refusing an invitation
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36.blurb: A monk who tricks another monk who has finished his meal into eating more, aiming to criticize him, must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc29.translated_title: 29. Eating food prepared on a nun’s instruction
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc29.blurb: A monk who eats almsfood that a nun has had prepared must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc67.blurb: A monk who travels by arrangement with a woman must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np12.translated_title: 12. Making a blanket entirely of black wool
pli-tv-bu-vb-np12.blurb: A monk who makes a blanket entirely of black wool must relinquish it and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc69.blurb: A monk who lives with a monk who has been ejected for holding the view that things declared as obstructive by the Buddha are not actually obstructive must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2.blurb: A monk who verbally abuses another monk must confess the offense. The origin story to this rule includes the Nandivisāla Jātaka tale, found in a slightly different form in the Jātaka collection.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc6.blurb: A monk who lies down in the same room as a woman must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc49.translated_title: 49. Staying more than three days with an army
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc49.blurb: A monk who stays with an army for more than three nights must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np17.translated_title: 17. Getting a nun to wash wool
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17.blurb: A monk who makes a nun wash, dye, or comb unspun wool must relinquish it and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-ay2.blurb: A female lay disciple may see a monk sitting in private with a woman. If she accuses him of an offense entailing suspension or confession, and he admits to the offense, then he incurs an offense accordingly.

pli-tv-bu-vb-ss3.blurb: A lustful monk who uses sexually explicit language when speaking to a woman is to be suspended.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc34.blurb: A monk who accepts more than three bowlfuls of pastries must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11.blurb: A monk who makes a blanket containing silk must relinquish it and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc86.blurb: A monk who makes a needle-case of bone, ivory, or horn must destroy it and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np18.blurb: A monk who receives money must relinquish it and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc23.blurb: A monk who teaches the nuns at their dwelling place must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc44.translated_title: 44. Sitting with a woman in a concealed place
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc44.blurb: A monk who, seeking privacy, sits in a secluded place with a woman must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-sk30.translated_title: 30. Not receiving on an even level

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc54.blurb: A monk who is disrespectful when rightly corrected about a breach of the monastic code must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc46.blurb: A monk who visits other lay people before or after an invitational meal must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc74.blurb: A monk who in anger strikes another monk must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc45.blurb: A monk who, seeking privacy, sits in private with a woman must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc76.blurb: A monk who falsely accuses another monk of an offense entailing suspension must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-sk29.translated_title: 29. Not receiving in the right proportions

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25.blurb: A monk who gives robe-cloth to another monk, but then takes it back in anger, must relinquish it and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3.blurb: A monk who spreads malicious gossip about another monk must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10.translated_title: 10. Excessive prompting to get a robe
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10.blurb: When money to be used for a monk’s robe has been placed with a steward in the proper way, that monk may hint to the steward that he needs a robe. If he does not get a robe in this way, but he does get one by acting inappropriately, he must relinquish the robe and confess the offense. This rule also prescribes the procedure through which a lay follower comes to hold money on behalf of a donor who wishes to support a monk.

pli-tv-bu-vb-ss2.blurb: A lustful monk who touches a woman is to be suspended.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38.blurb: A monk who eats food stored overnight must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41.blurb: A monk who gives food to a non-Buddhist mendicant must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pj.blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as pārājika. The exact meaning of the Pali word is disputed, but there is no doubt that it refers to expulsion from the Sangha. There are four such rules for the monks, all of which are shared with the nuns. Anyone who breaches any of these rules immediately loses his status as a monk. He is expelled from the Sangha and ineligible for re-ordination for the rest of his life. The pārājikas, together with the next category of rules, the saṅghādisesas, are collectively known as serious offenses, garukāpatti. These rules are the most fundamental ones for the proper living of the monastic life.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56.blurb: A monk who lights a fire to warm himself must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84.blurb: A monk who picks up anything considered valuable must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc4.translated_title: 4. Instructing a lay person to memorize the Teaching
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc4.blurb: A monk who teaches an unordained person to learn the word of the Buddha by heart must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3.translated_title: 3. Receiving food from a designated family
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3.blurb: A monk who receives food from anyone designated as “in training” must acknowledge the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np28.blurb: A monk who stores “an urgent robe” beyond the acceptable time limit must relinquish it and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np24.translated_title: 24. Making a rainy-season robe at the wrong time
pli-tv-bu-vb-np24.blurb: A monk who seeks or uses a rainy-season robe inappropriately must relinquish it and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc27.blurb: A monk who travels on a country road by arrangement with a nun must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc71.blurb: A monk who uses a ploy as an excuse for not keeping the monastic code must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-as.blurb: There are seven adhikaraṇasamathadhamma, “principles for the settling of legal issues”, which are the same for the nuns and the monks. These are not rules in the ordinary sense and as such fall outside of the classification into serious and light offenses. Instead, they set out the proper methods for dealing with legal issues. The detailed explanation for these is found in the Samathakkhandhaka. The legal issues to be settled through these principles fall into four categories: disputes, accusations, offenses, and proceedings. “Proceedings” includes monastic procedures such as ordination and the keeping of the observance day (uposatha).

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc12.blurb: A monk who speaks evasively or remains silent when questioned by the Order must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13.blurb: A monk who criticizes or denounces an official of the Order must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np3.translated_title: 3. Keeping extra robe-cloth beyond a month
pli-tv-bu-vb-np3.blurb: A monk may keep extra robe-cloth for a month if he is expecting more. A monk who keeps it beyond that must relinquish the robe-cloth and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39.blurb: A monk who asks for special food must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8.blurb: A monk who tells an unordained person about his own profound spiritual attainment must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68.translated_title: 68. Not giving up a bad view
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68.blurb: A monk who says that things declared as obstructive by the Buddha are not actually obstructive must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-ay.blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as aniyata, “undetermined”. There are two such rules for the monks, but none for the nuns. These are procedures to establish a course of action when a monk is accused of behaving in a sexually inappropriate way with a woman.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26.blurb: A monk who asks for thread and then has robe-cloth woven with it must relinquish the robe-cloth and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc77.blurb: A monk who intentionally makes another monk anxious must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6.translated_title: 6. Asking an unrelated person for a robe
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6.blurb: A monk who asks a lay person for robe-cloth, except if his robes are lost or destroyed, must relinquish the robe-cloth and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc21.blurb: A monk who teaches the nuns without the Order’s agreement must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc60.blurb: A monk who hides the requisites of another monk must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc50.blurb: If, while staying with an army, a monk goes to see the army in action, he must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc75.blurb: A monk who in anger physically threatens another monk must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc9.blurb: A monk who tells an unordained person about another monk’s serious offence must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc22.blurb: A monk who teaches the nuns after sunset must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np2.blurb: A monk who stays apart from any of his three robes for more than one day must relinquish the robe and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np22.translated_title: 22. Exchanging an almsbowl with fewer than five mends
pli-tv-bu-vb-np22.blurb: A monk who asks for a new bowl when his existing bowl is still useable must relinquish it and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc11.blurb: A monk who intentionally destroys vegetation must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc57.blurb: A monk in the central Ganges plain who bathes more than once a fortnight, except when dirty, must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13.blurb: A monk who causes the lay people in a certain place to lose confidence in the teachings of the Buddha should be banished from that place. If he refuses to accept the banishment, he is to be suspended. The introduction to this rule tells of the corrupt and merciless group of six monks, who were the offenders behind a large number of rules in the monastic code.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc63.blurb: A monk who tries to reopen an issue of monastic law that has been properly settled must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc79.blurb: A monk who has given his consent for the Order to perform an official act, but then criticizes the act, must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc1.blurb: A monk who lies must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc.blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as pācittiya, “entailing confession”. There are ninety-two such rules for the monks, seventy of which are shared with the nuns. This is the largest class of rules in the Monastic Code. These rules, together with all the other rules apart from those entailing expulsion and suspension, are classed as light offenses, lahukāpatti. For light offenses there is no penalty apart from confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np16.blurb: A monk who carries wool on a long journey must relinquish it and confess the offense.

kn.blurb: The word khuddaka means “lesser” or “minor”, and it seems that this category originally served to collect certain short collections, mostly verse, that were not conveniently assigned to one of the main nikāyas. Over time, however, the collection grew, so that the Khuddaka in the Pali canon today is the largest of the nikāyas. It includes some of the most popular texts in Theravāda Buddhism, such as the Dhammapada, the Sutta Nipāta, and the Jātakas. There is no closely parallel collection in the other canons, but many of the early texts have parallels in various places.

pli-tv-bi-vb.translated_title: The Nuns’ Rules and Their Analysis
pli-tv-bi-vb.blurb: The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the nuns’ rules”) contains the Monastic Code for nuns, the Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga is divided into seven chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them, with the exception of the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter. These units begin with one or more origin stories, which tell the circumstances that led the Buddha to lay down a particular rule. The rule is then stated, followed by a word commentary that analyzes every significant word contained in the rule. After the word commentary follows a permutation series in which a variety of different scenarios are evaluated and offenses assigned as appropriate. At the end comes a non-offense clause, stating important exceptions to the rule, sometimes followed by individual case studies, in which the Buddha decides the offense incurred in ambiguous cases.
